title: Just Read Act One: Thoughts Here!
body:
Good grief.

That was amazing. Finally we get a champion/champion dialogue! I don't think we've ever had that in all of league's lore!

And how spicy! Gangplank's an artist, who knew! Graves and Fate's relationship is one hell of a classic yet fresh experience to witness! Can this get any better?!

replies.body:
I was really digging the switching narrative between TF and Graves. Really cool and the story just damn good imo. 

Gangplank's characterization was really interesting. He's barbarous, murderous, a torturing bastard, but he gave that boy some coin and a warm meal. He's some kind of man. I dunno what kind of man, but some kind.

Some side notes I noticed: The Mother Serpent/Bearded Lady. I think this is the first time we've _ever_ had a primary deity named in League ever. She's a legit God in Bilgewater.

Also on the event page I noticed on the skins section it was divided between event skins and Bilgewater inspired skins. What interested me was that Cutpurse and Cutthroat TF and Graves had descriptions as if they're canon; a younger Graves and TF from a time when they were partners. There's also a third icon there. Makes me wonder what this implies for Miss Sarah Fortune in the coming acts...

> Gangplank's characterization was really interesting. He's barbarous, murderous, a torturing bastard, but he gave that boy some coin and a warm meal. He's some kind of man. I dunno what kind of man, but some kind.

I think the best word is 'fair'. He'll torture a man without a blink, scuttle a ship without a second thought, and hang any man that crosses him. But he'd also give his crew their fair cut of the pay, promote the men who've earned it and punish the slackers, and help out a street rat that gave him some vital information. He might not be nice, but it doesn't mean he's vile.

Although I don't like how humorless he is, he does seem to do what he does out of necessity rather than sadism or malice. He's not torturing a man because he gets hard to other people's suffering, he just needs to discipline a motherfucker every now and then so that they know who's the boss around here.
Yeah, seconded. It would have been nice to keep his sense of humor along with the craziness instead of making him toughdudebro #37

I mean, It'd be interesting if deep down he wasn't a vile person, if he was some sort of anti-villain who just wants to bring order to a city of anarchy, even if he has to become a monster in the process. I mean, it's implied, through the way he doesn't seem to derive any enjoyment from torturing a man.

He does everything for a purpose. His own gratification in that scene isn't his motivation. It's about making a point in a very particular way to everyone around him. I think you're picking up on that soundly.

Yes, I'm aware, I'm still yet to see if he does it out of some ultimately autristic reason (Wanting to bring order to Bilgewater), or just for him own sake (wanting to rule Bilgewater like a undisputed despot).

...Ok, to be fair, it could be both. The best benefactor of altruism is your bank account, that's my motto.

Gangplank sees himself as good for business all over. His own business first of all, of course, but if everyone plays along, everyone benefits. 

In Bilgewater, most people agree with that point of view. It's healthier.

Well, he kinda is, having every cutthroat, murderer, and thief have to answer to him IS better than complete anarchy.

...Does that make him Pirate Scarface?
Classic mob boss figures influenced us a lot in our thinking of who Gangplank is and how he interacts with Bilgewater.

A'right, cool. Now I have a reason to shout "SAY HELLO TO MY LITTLE FRIEND" when using Cannon Barrage.

Looking forward to the rest of the story. I hope this is the redemption for the Narrative Team, I wanna believe, this is where 8 months of waiting finally pay off.
eat and orange and be k, rito ate an orange and is making things k
This is definitely solid characterization, but I miss his humor and vivacity. Making even more characters sit solidly in super-somber city just doesn't feel right given this game's foundations.
Yeah, I'm all for the ruthless aspect, but I would just appreciate seeing him crack wise a bit more
Or hell, a fucking smile. There are way too many super serious characters in league as-is.
Patrician from Discworld skin for Gangplank.

Also helping out that street rat means word will spread. It's a really good way to cultivate sources of information from those that would go unnoticed by many. This isn't the first time he's got information this way. The denizens of the slaughter docks know the rules.

Interestingly Pirates were a pretty democratic and fair society in those kinds of terms. The Captain didn't divvy the loot though that was the Quartermasters job. The Captain is really there to give orders that will be followed mainly for the purposes of battle. Of course it varies from crew to crew.

Exactly the sort of man you'd expect to be able to lead pirates; the kind who does what is done to him.  To those who do him right, he rewards them; to those who do him wrong, *well*... let's just say you can't entirely rule the bloodthirsty and lawless without reminding them *why* it's better to follow you instead of mutiny.

> What interested me was that Cutpurse and Cutthroat TF and Graves had descriptions as if they're canon; a younger Graves and TF from a time when they were partners

Indeed, that's the concept.
oh, I didn't get that reference, that's cool! :D

As stated before, the characterization of Gangplank is like a king, or Machiavelli's "Prince", he is brutal and unbiased in his punishments, but he knows how to sell the fact that he's the most fit to lead Bilgewater. This makes him an exceedingly bad-ass character, and Miss Fortune's rivalry/threat to his position just makes the lore that much more exquisite. She's not fighting some irate pirate, she's facing a cunning politician and an even deadlier assailant. 

As for the new "religion", I love it! The immersion is getting that much more deep.

I'm getting the vibe that our girl Sarah was Twisted Fate's employer. But whatever the case, her role is going to be just as juicy as this little teaser.

Honestly this is the first time I've really been interested in the lore of League. I'm into a 
Out of lore of other games but League just has never been able to do it. The fact I love Pirates and Hives of Scum and Villainy and anything to do with Oceans and naval related stuff probably helps.

I do wonder how much of this will end up like the Shurima event where we get introduced to all the characters and get essentially what is the start of a story of characters we already knew existed and nothing significant will really happen to them. If all we're going to get are foundation stories for the entire cast of champions well we'll be getting foundation stories for a long time at this rate.

Responding to player feedback about Shurima was one of the underlying goals when we were writing Burning Tides. I hope you agree that significant changes have happened by the time the story is complete.

So, we're actually going to get the full story this time? With a beginning, middle, and actual end?

Because that'd actually be pretty damn nice. And I ain't being a snarky bastard about it either.

> [{quoted}](name=Jaredan,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=opAXAwfA,comment-id=00050000,timestamp=2015-07-22T01:44:26.200+0000)
>
> Responding to player feedback about Shurima was one of the underlying goals when we were writing Burning Tides. I hope you agree that significant changes have happened by the time the story is complete.

I rather liked it, particularly the part with Graves and TF. I also appreciated that it was [more backwards-compatible](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/rI1PN9Ms-bilgewater-hooray-for-backwards-compatible-lore) than some of the other "new lore".

My favorite little tidbit was the reference to a Demacian suit of armor.
I hope so too. I would love to actually get into this lore as a lot of the other lore I follow for other games is going downhill.

Thank you very much for this, Jaredan!
This is exceptionally well written thus far, and the last bit about Gangplanks' "art" was... you could say... chilling to the "bone." ;D
YEAAAAAAAAH
We hope you think so. Thank you for reading!

You know how on Client there use to be a place to read stories of Runeterra? Can you make a similar place but for these? I'd love to come back and reread these and what better place than on the server. It's like a book shelf for League champions, only digital.

Leblanc's Judgement had a conversation between the Matron of the Black Rose and Jericho Swain, as did the reveal of Sion's rework, and I'm sure you could find more than a few other examples if you went looking for them. It certainly isn't the first time we've had dialogue between Champions.

I'm going to reserve Judgement on this event for now because aside from Gangplank's piece, Act One ... honestly doesn't do much for me and I'm not quite sure why.

Character judgements were hallucinations, although I do understand that they had character dialogue, it never gave the sense that they were occurring in real time. I suppose you're right though.

I hope the story grows on you!

I suppose there's an argument for that, yes, even when things like the conversation in Leblanc's Judgement or the interaction between young Pantheon and Leona are obviously recreations of memories up to the point that the illusion needs to be broken. They're not _real_ conversations even if they are a window into those interactions.

I feel like I'm expecting more from the story or something. The interaction between Graves and TF feels totally by the numbers to me and the actual context of the story doesn't really contribute a whole lot to the narrative during their interaction. I want to see Graves' side of the story - how he tracked down TF and made his way into that warehouse the hard way - or to have more of a look into who sent TF to the warehouse rather than "Here's a bunch of exposition on Bilgewater's docks and gangs ... also I'm after a dagger."

(Deliberate hyperbole there. The first chapter has a lot of good information and certainly serves its purpose.)

I'm totally fine with Gangplank's Act. That's basically what I would be looking for in general as an Act One.

Edit:

One little touch that I will say I like is that TF always calls his former partner "Malcolm" in dialogue and "Graves" in his narration until desperation breaks his façade at the end of Part Three - “We’ve been sold out, Graves.”

I expect those missing details to reveal themselves in the coming Acts. Graves did mention swimming through the water to get into the warehouse, he had been waiting a long time and this helps allude to the fact that he was in fact tipped off. Its nice that this revelation was kept in TF's POV because Graves' POV is less contemplation and more fury and action. So we know there's some person tipping Graves off, and maybe we'll learn more about that in the future.

I have never liked anything Rito wrote when they decided to revamp the lore. However, this one actually caught my eye, after hearing a handful of people telling me it's actually good.

I mean, it has:

* champion/champion interaction, not some kind of champion/random person bullshit
* you get to know how someone speaks, and the kind of personality just by reading how they narrate and do stuff. Even clues on their pasts!
* clues that don't require language majors *just* to have the bare minimum idea on what the hell is going on
* extra tidbits that you never knew, such as GP being a humble man (or at least that's what it looks like) and an artist
* "glossary" of surrounding things, such as who the Jagged Hooks are

We *need* more of this kind of lore in LoL. More extra tidbit information, juicy drama of past and present relationships, and such. But I guess it *did* took them a while to get storytelling right...

Call me cynical, but although I found it to be quite good so far, I'm yet to see if they'll live up to the promise of actually start pumping out lore semi-regularly now that they're apparently nailed down the elusive tech issue.

I also have objections over how the Journal of Justice was terminated because it was boring reading text yet this lore update is almost all text, but I digress.
Agreed. But its sooooooo much better than just nothing, right!?
Yes, but I don't want to be left wanting again, Riot already did that twice, I don't need a third.
I read you. Third time's a charm, as they say!

I loved when Gangplank was explaining that "even the loyal forget their place" & "real power is about how people see you." It really meshes with the new update they're giving him. Now, you see how deeply ingrained the pirate life is for him, and why he is at the top. I have always been interested in the lores of League, and I have always loved the interconnectedness of a lot of the champions stories, especially TF and Graves. This little bit is beautiful for me.
Totally agree. It also shows a bit of weakness, though. With Sarah Fortune, Gangplank's reign is threatened, and we all know it, including the Pirate King himself...

In Regards to quality and quantity it is great!

However, if lore is still distributed in 8 month gaps, the story community is going to have at best 7 months of stagnation. 
I really hope Riot does awesome stuff like this every 8 months or so, but gives us something* in between for us to digest.

Otherwise we will quickly return to being all jaded without any new content to analyze/enjoy.

***Something involving old champion threads or plot progression and not new champions that are fairly disconnected ({{champion:421}} {{champion:432}} ) from the lore we already have.
